intro: Gaura glabra, commonly known as whorled gaura, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its slender, branching stems and clusters of delicate, pink or white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its foliage is typically lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, giving it a soft, fuzzy appearance. Gaura glabra is often grown in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators like butterflies and bees.
